title: documentation
content:
Project Documentation â€” NGO Website ğŸŒ Switch Language ğŸ“š Project Documentation â€” NGO Website README Architecture Forms HTML Validation Charts License README This repository contains the source code and documentation for an institutional website developed for a Non-Governmental Organization (NGO). The goal is to promote transparency, engagement, and facilitate communication with the public. ğŸ“ Project Structure projeto-ong/ â”œâ”€â”€ asset/ # Static files (CSS, JS, images, videos, etc.) â”œâ”€â”€ docs/ # Technical documentation in Markdown â”œâ”€â”€ *.html # Main website pages ğŸ§° Technologies Used HTML5 â€” Semantic page structure CSS3 â€” Styling and responsive layout Vanilla JavaScript â€” Interactivity and form validation Markdown (.md) â€” Technical documentation Visual Studio Code â€” Recommended code editor ğŸ“„ Website Pages index.html â€” Homepage sobre.html â€” Institutional information projetos.html â€” Project details transparencia.html â€” Financial transparency doacoes.html â€” Donation options voluntariado.html â€” Volunteer registration contato.html â€” Contact form blog.html â€” News and updates ğŸ“š Documentation All technical documentation is located in the docs/ folder and includes: arquitetura.md â€” Project architecture especificacoes-formularios.md â€” Form specifications graficos.md â€” Charts and visualizations validacao-html.md â€” HTML validation license.md â€” Usage and distribution terms README.md â€” This overview ğŸš€ How to Run Locally Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/your-username/projeto-ong.git Open the folder in VS Code: code projeto-ong Double-click index.html or use Live Server to preview in your browser. ğŸ¤ Contributions Contributions are welcome! Feel free to open issues or submit pull requests with improvements, fixes, or new features. ğŸ“„ License This project is licensed under the terms of the MIT License . ğŸ‘¤ Author Developed by Wellington LinkedIn â€¢ GitHub Architecture This section describes the overall architecture of the NGO website project, including folder structure, technologies used, page organization, and development principles. ğŸ“ Folder Structure projeto-ong/ â”œâ”€â”€ asset/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ audio/ # Audio files used on the site â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ css/ # Stylesheets â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ fonts/ # Custom fonts â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ img/ # Images used in pages â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ js/ # JavaScript scripts â”‚ â””â”€â”€ video/ # Video files â”œâ”€â”€ docs/ # Technical documentation in Markdown â”œâ”€â”€ blog.html # Blog page â”œâ”€â”€ contato.html # Contact page â”œâ”€â”€ doacoes.html # Donations page â”œâ”€â”€ index.html # Homepage â”œâ”€â”€ projetos.html # Projects page â”œâ”€â”€ sobre.html # About page â”œâ”€â”€ transparencia.html # Transparency page â””â”€â”€ voluntariado.html # Volunteer page ğŸ§ª Technologies Used HTML5 â€” Semantic structure of pages CSS3 â€” Styling and responsive layout Vanilla JavaScript â€” Interactivity and form validation Markdown (.md) â€” Technical documentation Visual Studio Code â€” Main code editor ğŸŒ Page Organization Each HTML page represents a specific section of the website: index.html â€” Homepage with NGO overview sobre.html â€” Institutional information projetos.html â€” Ongoing project details transparencia.html â€” Financial reports and accountability doacoes.html â€” Ways to contribute voluntariado.html â€” Volunteer registration and info contato.html â€” Contact form blog.html â€” Updates and publications ğŸ“± Responsiveness The site is designed to be responsive and user-friendly across: Mobile devices (smartphones and tablets) Modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari) Minimum recommended resolution: 360px ğŸ§­ Navigation and Usability Persistent main menu across all pages Internal and external links with visual feedback Semantic structure for accessibility (using
,
,
, etc.) Compatible with screen readers ğŸ”’ Best Practices Separation of concerns (HTML, CSS, JS in distinct folders) Clear and consistent naming conventions Code comments for clarity HTML validation via W3C tools Optimized fonts and images ğŸ“Œ Final Notes The project architecture is designed for easy maintenance, scalability, and collaboration. Its modular structure allows new pages and features to be added with minimal effort. Forms This section describes the forms used throughout the NGO website, including their purpose, fields, validations, and best practices. ğŸ“¬ Contact Form Purpose: Allow visitors to reach out to the NGO for questions, suggestions, or partnerships. Fields: Full name (required), Email (required), Subject (optional), Message (required) Validations: Valid email format, minimum 20 characters for message, name must not contain numbers Behavior: Displays success message after submission; may be integrated with email or backend ğŸ¤ Volunteer Form Purpose: Register individuals interested in volunteering for NGO projects. Fields: Full name (required), Email (required), Phone (optional), Area of interest (required), Availability (required), Additional message (optional) Validations: Valid email format, phone number with Brazilian mask, required fields must be filled Behavior: Data may be stored in a database or sent via email; may include consent for data usage (LGPD) ğŸ’° Donation Form Purpose: Facilitate donations from visitors. Fields: Name (optional), Donation amount (required), Payment method (required), Comment (optional) Validations: Minimum donation of R$10.00, required selection of payment method (Pix, credit card, boleto) Behavior: Redirects to payment gateway or displays QR code; may include automatic receipt âœ… Best Practices Use of label and placeholder for accessibility Visual feedback for invalid fields Clear and concise error messages Semantic grouping with
and Mobile-friendly layout ğŸ” Privacy Considerations All forms comply with Brazil's General Data Protection Law (LGPD) : Minimal data collection Explicit consent when required Clear purpose for each data field ğŸ“¦ Future Integrations (Suggestions) Integration with Google Sheets or Airtable for storing responses Automatic confirmation emails Admin dashboard to view submissions HTML Validation This section presents the validation tests performed on the NGO website's HTML pages, focusing on compliance with web standards, accessibility, and development best practices. ğŸ§ª Tools Used W3C Markup Validation Service â€” Official HTML validator: validator.w3.org Google Lighthouse â€” Auditing tool for performance, accessibility, and SEO HTMLHint â€” Real-time HTML code linter ğŸ“„ Validated Pages index.html sobre.html projetos.html transparencia.html doacoes.html voluntariado.html contato.html blog.html ğŸ› ï¸ Issues Fixed Unclosed tags (e.g., without /> ) Deprecated attributes removed (e.g., align , bgcolor ) Missing required attributes (e.g., alt for images) Improved semantic structure (replacing
with
,
, etc.) Duplicate id values corrected â™¿ Accessibility Use of aria-label and role for interactive elements Color contrast verified via Lighthouse Keyboard navigation tested manually Proper heading hierarchy (

to

) ğŸ“ˆ Lighthouse Audit Results Metric Average Score Performance 85/100 Accessibility 95/100 Best Practices 100/100 SEO 90/100 ğŸ“Œ Future Recommendations Implement automated tests with Jest or Cypress Add sitemap.xml and robots.txt files Use accessibility tools like Axe or Wave âœ… Conclusion All project pages have been successfully validated and comply with HTML5 standards. The site is optimized for accessibility, SEO, and cross-browser compatibility. Charts This section describes the charts used in the NGO website, including their purpose, types, data sources, and visual best practices. ğŸ¯ Purpose of Charts Present data in a visual and accessible way Reinforce the NGOâ€™s commitment to transparency Make complex information easier to understand Engage visitors with dynamic content ğŸ“ Chart Locations transparencia.html â€” Displays financial and impact data projetos.html â€” Shows project progress and results doacoes.html â€” Presents donation statistics ğŸ“ˆ Chart Types Type Purpose Page Pie Expense distribution transparencia.html Bar Donation comparison by period doacoes.html Line Project evolution over time projetos.html ğŸ› ï¸ Tools Used Chart.js â€” Lightweight and responsive JavaScript chart library Google Charts (optional) â€” Alternative for external data integration Custom CSS â€” Styling to match site identity ğŸ“Š Data Sources Internal NGO reports Financial control spreadsheets Volunteer and donation records Social impact indicators ğŸ¨ Visual Best Practices Accessible and contrasting colors Clear legends and labels Descriptive titles for each chart Responsive layout for mobile devices Periodic data updates ğŸ”„ Chart Updates Charts are updated manually or via spreadsheet integration. Recommended practices: Monthly data updates Visual review for each new campaign or project Data validation before publishing ğŸ“Œ Final Notes Using charts on the NGO website enhances transparency and credibility. It also improves user experience by presenting data in a clear and engaging format. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN THE SOFTWARE. ğŸ“Œ Notes This license allows others to use, modify, and distribute the project, including for commercial purposes. Credit to the original author and license notice must be retained. The project is provided without warranty , and the author is not liable for any issues arising from its use. ğŸ¤ Contributions Contributions are welcome! By contributing to this project, you agree that your code will be released under the same MIT License terms. Developed by Wellington â€¢ NGO Website Project
